title.narrative: FLC/ WiLDAF Promoting Women?s Participation in Democratic and Electoral Process

description.narrative: Despite efforts from government development partners and civil society organisations to build the capacity of women candidates and to advocate with political parties and law-making institutions the number of women as elected parliamentarians dropped from 1 4% in 2006 to 11.4% in 2011; and the number of women elected as councillors remained unchanged at the low level of 6.1%. The voter turn-out in the 2011 elections also decreased to 54% from 71% in 2006 and 68% in 2001. Registered voters in Zambia are overwh elmingly young with 54% aged between 18 to 35 and the previous elections showed a large proportion of first time voters (25% of registered voters). Still most young people especially young women lack knowledge about democratic and electoral processes and b asic civic awareness to be able to meaningfully participate in political and decision-making processes. Against this context WiLDAF?s project aims to increase meaningful participation and representation of women and girls in electoral and democratic proces s in six districts of Zambia. Specifically the proposed initiative seeks to achieve three interrelated results: 1) Increasing number of women as elected candidates in the 2016 local elections through mainstreaming gender into the existing legal and elector al framework advocacy with political parties for formulation and adoption of gender-positive measures or quota system in the party capacity building of prospective women candidates and organisation of regional network forum for prospective women candidates and women?s party leagues for experience and information sharing; 2) Enhancing capacity of young women to actively and meaningfully participate in democratic and electoral process through establishment and support of well-functioning girls? clubs promotio n of youth debates on democratic and electoral issues and increasing community awareness on key democratic concepts and electoral process; and3) Strengthening democratic process and practices at the local level through state and non-state dialogue mechanis m to increase the focus on women?s issues and enhance the culture of constructive interaction between the two actors. The project?s direct beneficiaries are the prospective women candidates for the council election in 2016 and women from women?s leagues of key political parties young women and men aged 16 to 25 and community members including religious and traditional leaders parents and teachers.
